Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Community Energy: Technical and Social Challenges and Integrative Solutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The concept of Community Energy involves integrating small-scale solar power, demand management and energy storage at the community level to create economic, environmental and social value for individuals and communities while improving the reliability and resilience of the electric grid. While this concept has great potential benefits, it raises a number of conceptual issues that must be addressed to realize its potential. These include: (1) How economic and behavioral incentives are perceived and valued in a community context and whether these differ from the perceptions and values of individual energy users; (2) How residents and other stakeholders will perceive such a project and what factors affect their acceptance and participation; (3) How highly granular data can be analyzed, visualized, and communicated to encourage acceptance and facilitate participation in a Community Energy program. To address these issues, this planning project brings together residents and stakeholders in the Mueller community of Austin, Texas, to create knowledge and tools to develop a Community Energy program that will serve as a model for other communities across the U.S. Planning and developing such a project will engage residents and stakeholders at each stage to maximize the probability of success. The results of the research will be published in academic, policy and practitioner outlets, and the data analysis and visualization tools will be distributed freely to researchers, policymakers and practitioners. The planning project will support and train graduate students at Syracuse University in research methods that integrate social science and data science in an active research setting.

There is an urgent need to improve the reliability and resilience of the electric grid and to integrate new technologies such as rooftop solar, battery storage and electric vehicles. These technologies can strain an aging grid that was not designed to handle them, but if managed properly can actually provide valuable resources to the grid such as demand response and load shifting. These benefits are greater if aggregated at the community level. However, this requires gaining the understanding and participation of community members and developing tools to analyze, visualize and communicate large, heterogeneous datasets to a variety of stakeholders. This multidisciplinary, integrative project addresses these issues through (1) identifying and engaging key community stakeholders, (2) conducting community workshops and implementing a survey of community members in the Mueller neighborhood (3) developing data analytics, visualization and communication tools that integrate data on electricity use, weather, and location factors, in consultation with targeted stakeholders and community members, and (4) developing a full proposal to implement the Community Energy program in the Mueller community. The project involves collaboration with the Pecan Street Institute in Austin, which collects detailed household electricity data on over 300 homes in the Mueller neighborhood and has well-established relationships with residents, local government, developers and the local business community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid adoption of renewable energy has created the need for a more agile and resilient electric grid. Solar and wind power are variable resources and their availability often does not match electricity demand. While energy storage can alleviate some of the temporal mismatch between demand and supply, it is still relatively expensive and unproven at large scale.  Another option is for energy users to change their electricity consumption to better match available supply. However, the huge gap in scale between the energy use of individual consumers and the needs of the entire grid makes it difficult to demonstrate to consumers how their individual actions can make a meaningful difference. We hypothesize that collective action at the community level to manage energy demand will lead to better results than demand response programs that target individual users only.

There have been a number of community-level projects to manage energy consumption, but most lack a comprehensive approach to changing the community?s ?energy culture,? which is the constellation of forces that impact the energy choices individuals and communities make. Shifting energy behavior requires changing what people have (technologies), how they think (attitudes, awareness, motivation), and what they do (behavior).

The goals of this project were to gain the necessary understanding of local energy culture to create a plan for a local energy management program in the Mueller community, a ?green? development in Austin, TX. The specific goals included (1) understanding how residents and other stakeholders respond to the community-level energy management concept; (2) identifying motivations and obstacles to participation; (3) identifying factors in the energy culture that influence favorability of residents? response to the concept; and (4) developing tools to collect, analyze, visualize, and communicate detailed energy data so that participants can understand and manage their energy use.

The project team collaborated with Pecan Street, Inc. and the Mueller community to conduct interviews with stakeholders, a workshop and focus groups with 22 local residents, and a survey of 85 residents. The team developed initial designs for a dashboard and mobile phone application to enable residents to manage their energy use.

The main findings are as follows:

Residents showed a positive response to the idea of a community-based energy management program. They state that they?d be likely to alter their own energy use, but they are less optimistic that their neighbors will participate, even though they generally believe that their neighbors are willing to work together to solve common problems.

The most important motivations to participate are societal benefits and environmental impacts. Less importance was placed on contributing to a community fund. Some residents favored contributing to a fund that would benefit other Austin communities who have greater needs than Mueller. A major concern of residents was that the results would not be relevant to communities with different socioeconomic conditions than the relatively affluent Mueller community.

The factors which had the greatest impact on the favorability of residents? responses to the proposed program were individual and social norms. Individual norms include feeling a strong obligation to conserve energy, regardless of what others think or do. Social norms reflect experience working with community members to solve other problems, believing that a community can work together to achieve common goals, and strong community expectations regarding individual energy use. Surprisingly, material culture (what technologies residents have) and self-efficacy (ability to access and use energy information) did not have a significant impact on favorability.  These results point to the importance of measuring energy culture in each community to understand what factors might drive residents? response and ultimately their likelihood to participate.

Regarding the information residents would need to participate, community participants saw high value in information that would help them better track and manage their individual use, including alerts when something was behaving in an unusual manner and seeing a breakdown of energy use for each appliance. Information about renewables use at the individual and community level was also highly valued, while community engagement was less valued.

The most significant results from the project are (1) understanding the nature of the energy culture and how it has developed in a relatively new community with previous experience with energy projects, (2) measuring the level of interest in an energy management project on the part of residents and community stakeholders, and the goals that would be most salient for this community, (3) gaining insight into how the program should be designed to maximize participation and achieve community goals, (4) receiving input into the design of energy monitoring and management tools such as a dashboard and mobile application.
